Fahrenheit in the shade. On the other hand, forty-nine below zero, or eighty-one degrees of frost, is the lowest aqtually recorded in Man- churis. Generally speaking, in the south the average winter minimum is not much below zero Fahrenheit. But what the armies have chiefly to fear is the north wind, which is the terror of Manchi When it blows no cover ing of furs is sufficient to keep out the piercing cold, and life in the open will be almost un- bearable, especially, for men doomed to outpost Barum Wind Temp. and sentry work at night. Fortunately, this

awful wind rarely lasts three days; and in its absence the winter sun shines so Slight brightly that the dry cold is not felt. Stight When once the country becomes ice-bound and Rather the rivers and streams are frozen over, the 18.0 sight tactics and even the strategy of the opposing armies will be greatly affected. The side adopting the defensive will find that the rivers have completely disappeared as a calculable A factor, and can no longer be reckoned upon as useful tactical obstacles to the passage of an assailant. complete transformation of the conditions of warfare, which will bestow a unique interest upon this campaign, already so fruitful in sur Another thing we may look for is.a great increase in mobility. As soon as the prises. country roads and tracks have been worn down they acquire the smoothness almost of an asphalt roadway in Alexandria. With the new possibility of moving in all directions without let or hindrance, the scope of the cavalry arm will be greatly enlarged. Accordingly, until April and May next we may be on the lookout for many new features in the winter struggle between the rival armies.

It is thought that France and Russia would not be favourable to union in the near future; the relations between-Italy and Greece are not particularly good, the Italians and the Greeks are rivals in Epirus, and the compulsory recall of the Italian Minister from Athens last spring did not improve the feelings of the two races: Great Britain has no special interest, in hindering, or in hastening, the union, except that, when once the Greeks have Crete, they will demand-Cyprus, which is always regarded by them as an Hellenic island. MUKDEN, November 22. Owing to the strength of the respective positions, neither army appears inclined to attack unless possessing such a preponderance in numbers that they are able to make a flank ing movement. The Japanese probably have the most available troops. (Reuter.)

PARIS, November 22. It is stated here that, at the request, of Great Britain, the Russian officer, of the transport Kamchatka, who first gave the order to open fire on the trawlers, has been landed at Dakar. He will appear before the Commis sion of Inquiry.

BLIND SCHOOLS-A "bazaar in aid of the blind schools at Alexandria and Tantah will be held at the residence of Mrs. Coventry (which has been kindly lent for the purpose), Mansourah, on Friday next, at 2 p.m. The sale is under the patronage of Mrs. B. Dale.
CANEA, November 22. A division of the Baltic Fleet has left for Port Said. It consists of two battleships, three cruisers, six destroyers, and nine transports. (Reuter.)

A nautical correspondent writes: in the Red Sea on the look-out for the Russian If the Japanese are lurking about somewhere fleet, the most likely spot for them to be lying Daedalus lighthouse, to the north-east of in waiting is in the neighbourhood of the Berenice. The reefs run out there in every direction and yet one cannot touch bottom in 300 fathoms with deep sea lead. The Japanese could place two torpedo-boats there, one on the east and one on the west of the channel, and they could knock the Russians into a cocked hat at this point.

VIENNA, November 22. According to an official statement issued here, the Austro-Russian reform scheme has greatly improved the general condition of Macedonia. The population itself desires pence. (Router)

LONDON, November 22, Cin a memorandum by Prince George, handed to the Powers, he emphasizes the certainty of disorders in Crete, if the people's aspirations for the union to Greece are again, rejected.

THE AMERICAN ANNUAL NATIONAL THANKS- GIVING will be observed to-morrow (Thursday). In recognition of this anniversary, & service will be held at 11 o'clock to-morrow in the American Mission Church, Cairo, near Shep- heard's Hotel: Residents and visitors are cordially invited to participate in this service.

SURZ CANAL-On the 19th and 20th inst. 33 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 24 were British, 2 French, 4 German, Dutch, 1 Austrian, and I Portuguese. The transit and passenger dues for the two days amounted to 884,032.02 fra. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 298 vessels amounted to 6,612,139.09 frs.
The Khedive is spending to day at Mariout, where he is inspecting his estates. His Highness will return to Montazah in the evening.

Heavy C bags were also largely takes at Rs. 25-6, both by speculators and Burmah skippers, right on to Jute next year, and with the Straits and Far East operating later the tendency is to a higher level of prices. THESSIANS are firmer and do not look like giving way in value. Rs, 12-4 is the nominal quotation for wheat bags, with no sellers, while Rs. 10 has been paid for 40 10 jo eloth for Jan./June, and Rs. 7-14 for 40 8 oz. Jan./March and Rs. 7-12 April-June. FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT) PARIS, November 7. We have taken so kindly to English ways that, for two days this week, we were enjoying Landin particular-almost. The fog was not quite of the yellowish hue that prevails by the banks of the Thames, but it had sufficient sistency-and a sufficient blackness to cause general fighting up at noon. I have just meta French friend, who said, "I have come from London. Do you know-it is astonish ing there was no fog there. The first I saw was at Havre, where the boat had to remain half an hour outside the harbour because of it. The cold and the rain and the fog are the usual heralds of the winter, in Paris. If wish for another sign you have it in the you disconsolate crowd that besieges the doors of the municipal, refuges. It says something for British prosperity that of the fifteen hundred of all nationalities applying for relief last month, only one spoke with the tongue of the Englishman.
